sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using Cramer's rule
message_1:
Solve the system of linear equations using Cramer's rule: 

$2x + 3y = 7$ 

$4x - 5y = -19$
message_2:
To solve the given system of linear equations using Cramer's rule, we first need to find the determinant of the coefficient matrix, which we'll call D. The coefficient matrix is:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
2 & 3 \\
4 & -5
\end{bmatrix}
$$

The determinant D is calculated as follows:

$$
D = (2 \times -5) - (3 \times 4) = -10 - 12 = -22
$$

Now, we need to find the determinants of the matrices formed by replacing the columns of the coefficient matrix with the constants from the right-hand side of the equations. We'll call these determinants D_x and D_y.

For D_x, replace the first column of the coefficient matrix with the constants:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
7 & 3 \\
-19 & -5
\end{bmatrix}
$$

Calculate the determinant D_x:

$$
D_x = (7 \times -5) - (3 \times -19) = -35 + 57 = 22
$$

For D_y, replace the second column of the coefficient matrix with the constants:

$$
\begin{bmatrix}
2 & 7 \\
4 & -19
\end{bmatrix}
$$

Calculate the determinant D_y:

$$
D_y = (2 \times -19) - (7 \times 4) = -38 - 28 = -66
$$

Now, we can find the values of x and y using Cramer's rule:

$$
x = \frac{D_x}{D} = \frac{22}{-22} = -1
$$

$$
y = \frac{D_y}{D} = \frac{-66}{-22} = 3
$$

So, the solution to the system of linear equations is:

$$
x = -1, y = 3
$$
